{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3385902,"name":null,"username":"asha1","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/asha1/{size}/227465_2.png","created_at":"2024-05-14T21:02:31.669Z","cooked":"

Hello, we would like to have improvement ideas for our robot’s elevator, we struggled with both chain and rope system for it. Rope system powered with 2 neo vortexes 4:1 and 5:1 on each motor seemed to be able to carry us but it kept slipping because the tension wasn’t enough, and when it would spool, it would reach the end of the spool and get tangled which eventually made it snap after every match so we switched up to chain drive afterwards. With chain drive powered by again 2 neo vortexes but 5:1 and 9:1 on each motor would extend but we couldnt even made a successful climb, something seems to be off and we couldn’t figure out… would appreciate any help!
An image of what we did with spool

Elevator_-Updated_Rigging-_Down_Position1088×948 155 KB

and the CAD model of the robot
24 - Crescendo - Robot “Zelda”

Spools can be very annoying, so stopped using them. We use a single center chain on the first stage, and rope on successive stages. By using a complete loop rather than up and down ropes you eliminate the need for spools. If you do want to use spools make them a large diameter and be prepared for them to unreel and a variable rate. I’ve seen a couple elevators use webbing which would behave much more predictably but at the expense of size and ability to turn in any direction.

Beyond the spool issue, I think you probably just need a higher reduction. In ‘23 I’m pretty sure we used a 3stage MP (probably 60:1, but my memory could be off) and a single motor. Assuming your motors aren’t mechanically tied together you could have them pull the elevator out of alignment and cause a jam, but that’s fairly unlikely.

","post_number":2,"post_type":1,"posts_count":7,"updated_at":"2024-05-14T21:32:37.310Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":2,"reads":499,"readers_count":498,"score":139.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":466244,"topic_slug":"elevator-improvements","display_username":"Patrick","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":4}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":52597,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Build mentor"},"post_url":"/t/elevator-improvements/466244/2","custom_user_title":"Build mentor","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":2},{"id":"100","type":"emoji","count":1},{"id":"point_up","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":4,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3386029,"name":"","username":"Alex_Y","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/a/82dd89/{size}.png","created_at":"2024-05-15T01:37:07.459Z","cooked":"
asha1:

slipping because the tension wasn’t enough,

I don’t see a spring tensioner there, but there are there problem happening. Whenever a spool doesn’t feed well, the lack of tension is usually a symptom of the problem, rather than the actual problem with the system.

I would take a look at your fleet angle, anything more than a few degrees and they don’t spool well because it will feed at different rates through the travel. You can reduce your fleet angle by either running larger-diameter spools and/or increasing the distance before the rope hits a pulley. In the image you posted, the rope on the extension side only needs to go a few inches before getting redirected upwards, which isn’t a very long distance. What teams have historically done is ran the rope directly upwards with the first redirection on the top of the robot so you get 3-4 ft or so of rope length before the first redirection, which results in much lower fleet angles.

Another issue that’s visible is something I like to call “triangling” where your ropes aren’t feeding perfectly parallel. Looking at your carriage here, the rope between the 2nd stage and the carriage is not close to parallel. What happens is that as the carraige travels up, the angle in which the triange your rope is making changes which results in the amount of taken up rope being more than the distance the carraige is actually traveling, causing spools to effectively not feed at the same rate and take up rope at the same rate, causing a tension loss.

image184×686 64 KB

My suggestion would be to try continuous rigging instead of cascade rigging. While you have to spool more rope up, you only have to deal with the spooling and tensioning once vs cascade where you have to tension the rigging multiple times and keep everything in sync. This saves on all the complexity and weight of dealing with multiple coupled rope loops along with providing a few more minor benefits.

I would give a look at 3d printing spools if possible and inserting a channel for the rope to run through in your cad model. It gives it a reliable spot to go to every time and can help reduce entanglement.

Any time you have cable going between two moving parts and it ISN’T parallel to the motion, the cable is changing length. For a fixed length cable, that means you do one of these: break it, jam it, or damage your mechanism.

So, big win is to adjust your pulley diameters and locations so ALL of your runs that jump between moving parts are parallel to the motion. If the cable is going between two pulleys that are BOTH on the same mechanical part, the angle doesn’t matter.

To be specific, the blue to yellow run with grey cable has a lot of angle. Red cable going from black to blue looks suspicious too, but better.

Do everything you can to keep mass low. So find a way to move as many motors as you can down low. Added benefit of less wiring.
